author: InvestingBig
body:
What is interesting about Cisco is it actually produced 3 billion profits a year with only a PE of 200. It also was growing revs like 50% a year and profits 30-50%. Like tesla it was in a "transformative" industry. Unlike Tesla, it was also nearly the only game in town and it's products had real network effects (unlike cars).

More interesting, the bubble "popped" and it lost 80% of it's value. When the share price popped it's revenue / income were continuing to grow, so it did not "pop" based on some loss of customers or business. It was not until 1 year later, when it's stock price had already bottomed, that it finally showed a bad quarter report.

Tesla holders should look at the parallels with Cisco and realize even if Tesla's future looks bright does not mean it's share price does.

author: xothixchoi
body:
[https://simplywall.st/stocks/ca](https://simplywall.st/stocks/ca)

This is a mandatory step for me before I buy any stock. I keep most of my holdings in ETFs as well, so when I stock pick, I'm very stringent. I don't focus as much on stocks that "have huge potential to grow" (since one can very often be wrong on that) but more on established stocks that "can't fall much lower than now", although it's obviously best to be both but that's rare. 

So when I see a big name stock that's strangely low, I check here for the risks that have caused it, and do further research into it to see if it's a temporary issue that the company should recover from, or if it's a company-killing concern. For example, I'd buy Coca Cola or Cisco now (also solid dividen stocks), but I'd be cautious with Pfizer or Barrick Gold.

author: NoAtmosphere2271
body:
Converge Technology Solutions ($CTS.V) is not a penny stock but it might as well be. I have no clue what they do but their trading multiples make absolutely zero sense. Their market cap is less than this years revenue, and their last quarter was profitable. Share price of 6 something when it should be at least double. It’s uplisting to the TSE is set for February 17th and I would recommend hopping onboard this choo choo train before it hits double digits. Institutional ownership sits at a mere 3.8%. Insiders have bought ~950K shares in the past 12 months and own ~12.3%. They haven’t sold a single share and the biggest holder is the CEO at 8.13%. The company has made something like 17 acquisitions in North America since October 2017 and have plans to expand into Europe in the future. If you need any more convincing, go look at the list of their platinum sponsors for next weeks #ConvergeConnect21 conference.. You might recognize some of the companies: IBM, Redhat, Google Cloud, Microsoft, Dell, VMware, AWS, PureStorage, Cisco, and Snowflake. Lenovo and PaloAlto are two of the gold sponsors. Hewlett-Packard and Intel are two of the silver sponsors. This is a Constellation Software-like company in the making- MASSIVE. Their latest bought financing closed today fully subscribed for a mere 80+ million dollars. Guess what they plan to do with it that money- M&A. Did I forget to mention that they are very likely to break a billion in revenue this year? Oh yeah and they’re still on the venture exchange! 

TLDR: CTS.V - strong buy before Q4 earnings (don’t know when they are), or at least before uplisting to TSE in mid Feb. Thank you.

author: thirtydelta
body:
I'm pleasantly surprised to see the growing attention Nokia is receiving. I didn't expect it to hit r/wallstreetbets this soon. When I speculate for large returns, I try to find companies like this that have high value risk/reward. 

Positions,
1. 200x 19 Feb 2021 $6C
2. 200x 21 Jan 2022 $4C

So, why is NOK an interesting risk/reward play? I'll list a few reasons in general terms, unless specifics are requested.

1. *Recent sentiment shift*:  Nokia has shown improved quarterly earnings, and secured several major 5G deployments. As a result, we're seeing more news, publications and analysis that reflect a bullish outlook.

2. *Undervaluation*: Nokia trades at a lower forward earnings compared to its competitors, such as Erickson and Cisco. While Erickson has risen over 35% during 2020, Nokia has remained flat. I believe this will soon change as Nokia gains recognition for its recent growth and partnerships. 

3. *Partnerships*: Quite recently, Nokia announced new and expanded partnerships with Google, for cloud-native network functions, T-Mobile, for a five year 5G network rollout, DTAC for 5G services throughout Thailand, a sole supplier deal for Taiwan Mobile's 5G network, and over [60 additional deals](https://www.nokia.com/about-us/news/releases/2020/01/09/nokia-highlights-momentum-with-63-commercial-5g-deals/) with companies such as AT&T, Sprint, Verizon, Vodafone, Softbank, and others. 

4. *Leadership*: Appointed less than a year ago, Nokia is now operating under Pekka Lundmark, who serves as president and CEO. The old and rotten days of Rajeev Suri are over. One of the main reasons they appointed Lundmark was to drive shareholder value. 

5. *Early Stage*: While sentiment is growing and new deals are being minted, Nokia has yet to reemerge into the top tier investment news cycle. This is important because it's an indicator that you're entering into a position before hype is occurring. 

6. *Premium Cost/Secure Floor*: The premium cost for options, including LEAPS is cheap enough to make this worth a risk/reward play. While you could doubt the growth potential, Nokia operates a strong and growing business that provides a secure floor for share price. Thus, I don't have any concern of my options dumping due to a large drop in the underlying. You will pay around an 8% premium/share ratio for options, which is obviously higher than your bluechip stocks, which are around 4-5%, but this is because the value proposition is so high. 

Why do I have leaps and monthlies? The leaps are self-explanatory. The monthlies are so cheap, that I'm willing to front the cost incase Nokia gains traction sooner than later, which it appears to be doing. 

TL:DR; NOK 200x 19 Feb 2021 $6C 🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀🚀

author: Im_shorting_elon
body:
I wouldn't say the market itself is in a bubble but certain sectors are. Big ones right off the bat are the Energy/EV sector (TSLA, ENPH, PLUG, NIO, etc.), the Genomics sector (EDIT, CRSPR, FATE, PACB), some tech/cloud (APPS, SE, FVRR), and some miscellaneous stocks (PENN!!!, RICK, CELH) etc. Genomics and EV specifically because they are supposedly the future. No doubt they are but that's what everyone was saying about the internet back in 1999, 2000, and it really took about 10 years for those stocks that crashed but survived to *really* get going (MSFT, ADBE, AMZN, PCLN, etc.), some haven't even recovered still, such as Cisco and MicroStrategy.

Do keep in mind that the DOW has risen 12k+ points in just 10 months and some bubbles have already popped or on the decline (think NKLA or ZM).

When you say "everyone", do you mean people on this subreddit or people in your daily life? I've noticed on these forums people are a bit more cognizant of what's going on, so they know that a lot of these valuations don't make sense but in the outside world, I know and have heard of plenty of people buying stocks on Robinhood because "BuY tHe DiP!!" is constantly blasted on social media and through word of mouth. For example, I know someone who bought US Foods on Robinhood for no particular reason. 

These stocks go down once:

A. Fed decides to increase interest rates

B. Black Swan Event, which is possible given the state of affairs at this point in time.

author: Accurate_Link_2992
body:
Some examples...

ETF: ARKQ

Individuals: ABB, ROK, KUKAY, OMRNY, YASKY


I’m in the industrial automation field and those are all companies that I have personally used. 

ABB robots are my favorite. 

Yaskawa is my favorite for general motion control. 

Rockwell is more on the side of general industrial control and not robots, but they are huge. For example, they make the control system components and platforms that control the whole system and the robots are a part of that larger system. 

CSCO does a lot with industrial networking. For example, Rockwell’s managed ethernet switches are essentially housings with CISCO Guts. 

Also, if Inductive Automation ever goes public, BUY IT.

author: evader9992
body:
You're spot on, and I'll add that Microsoft took FOURTEEN years after 2000 to return to its bubble levels. And this is one of the greatest companies of all time, one of the few success stories out of dozens of failures.

Also, even though Amazon is seen as a winner in the long-run, it was down from its 2000 high of $1000 to a price of $8 in 2001! EIGHT dollars! 92 percent drop. Even though Amazon recovered 10 years later, is anyone going to be able to stomach a 92% drop? I doubt it. Way better to get out now, and look to buy at a reasonable level, even if you think the stock is a winner in 15 years. Obviously it's impossible to be smart enough to buy at the trough at $8, but at least get out now, and buy after a 50% drawdown or something similar.

Whenever people say that Microsoft and Amazon worked out in the end, that's classic survivorship bias. Even solid companies like Cisco aren't anywhere near their 2000 levels today, and of course other companies like [PETS.com](https://PETS.com) which people thought were great, went to zero. Buyer beware.

author: Power80770M
body:
I was also there for it, having opened my first brokerage account in '98 or '99. Lost most of the college summer money I made buying high flyers like EMC.

One argument I hear from people nowadays it's that "it's nothing like dotcom, the high flyers today are actually PROFITABLE!" This argument implies two things:

* The only high flyers back then were companies with no profits; and 
* There aren't many money-losing high flyers today

Both of those ideas are patently false. Back then, most profitable companies had insane valuations; and there were the "Four Horsemen" - Microsoft, Oracle, Cisco, Dell - that were hugely profitable AND had truly insane valuations. Also, there are a huge number of money losing companies nowadays. Look at any IPO of the past year - look at the entire SaaS industry - huge money losers all around. 

It's not different this time. It will come crashing down.

author: noveltieaccount
body:
Thanks for providing some supporting evidence. I would say my only remaining question, which I'm not sure we can actually properly answer with the available data, is whether or not all this capital flowing into railroad investments during the 19th century would have yielded investors with returns. Capital can flow into a sector without ever being returned to shareholders and I think this could have been the case with something like the early days of railroads. The capital would have been used to develop new technology and build infrastructure and many of these companies would have been leveraged and in a environment with high competition. As you mention, we know that some of them paid dividends, but would that actually offset the cost of other railroads going out of business and their stock going to zero?

I remembered this podcast that I listened to recently that talks about investing in technological revolutions and they mention the railroad mania as an example. Part of the idea is that some companies will come out of these tech revolutions and winners and some will come out as losers, but it's often very hard to predict who. You can think of the tech bubble in 2000 as an example, almost everyone thought Cisco would be huge, but they still haven't reached their previous high from 2000. On the other hand, no one would have predicted Amazon, a book seller would be what it is today. In the same way, if you'd invested in Kansas City Southern 100 years ago you'd be very happy, but if you'd invested in The Ann Arbor Railroad you would have lost everything.

Here is a link to the podcast if you are interested. They also go into some of the theories, based on the efficient market hypothesis, that try to explain the returns that typically come out of these tech revolutions: https://rationalreminder.ca/podcast/123

author: Assume_Utopia
body:
Cisco is one of the few big name internet stocks of the dot com boom that didn't either go out of business/get acquired, and also hasn't exceed it's 2000 stock price. Intel is the other one I can think of. Then there's some like microsoft that are clearly much higher than their peak in 2000, but the return from the peak then to now would still give a fairly low yearly compounded return.

But that was largely driven by a bubble in the market/sector. Good companies had their valuations inflated and terrible companies were able to raise money to get started before burning out a couple years later. 

We're certainly not in a general automotive bubble right now, if anything the valuations of most other large automakers appear somewhat depressed. Maybe we're in an "EV bubble", but Tesla is basically the entire investable market?

Is there another situation where a single stock had a bubble where it was driven up purely on expectations of higher prices in the future, and then crashed?

Personally, I don't really agree with this BofA note, the ability to raise capital is great, but it's pointless if you don't have useful things to spend it on, or can't spend it efficiently. Tesla seems to be in a somewhat unusual situation where even though they're building and ramping up factories very quickly, they're limited mostly by how many factories they can build at the same time? That's a problem that can be helped a bit by capital raises, but they've probably already hit the point of diminishing returns for throwing money at construction projects to get more of them done, faster.

author: Ttowner
body:
With this. It’s an ignorant position to try to leverage your own inaction based on the possible loss of others. While yes this is r/value investing we need to understand that the paradigm is changing. I’ve been “value investing” since putting all my high school money in Cisco in 2000 after reading buffetology and seeing some good specs. I did ok, but today I made over 100x that return on GME. In a day. 

A small proportionate position to my play portfolio (independent of my retirement), yet things are changing. Evolve or die. Don’t champion on the possible losses of others, especially to makeup for a rough red day. 

Position wise? I’m 30k play money, up 7k GME, bought at 30 and took profits the whole way up. My ETFs and “safe” stocks (less MSFT) all took major hits.

The world is changing. Let us not discredit or discount the bold that test the boundaries. Let us learn.

author: Jy_sunny
body:
Literally 80% on here lose. We’re just gambling addicts. We post rockets on plays we’re winning on, and shut up about our losses. Human nature. 

That’s literally why the bears come out of their holes PM and AH, while they hibernate during trading hours.   

Also, don’t buy into something when it’s already up massively. It’s due a correction and rarely continues its streak. Tesla being the exception. 

Once in a while, dabble in reliable, long-existing value companies, and realize your 20% profit.   

Examples are commodities, MMM, older tech companies like IBM and CSCO, KO, KHZ, AAL, INTC, and banking. Buy longer dated options on reliable sectors that haven’t yet caught up to their loss from covid.  

If you ask me, renewable energy ETFs are fine, but man, don’t get into stocks like plug, blnk. They’ve run up 100% in a year, which isn’t sustainable

author: smilingyoda
body:
>You already have the shares, so you would only have to wait until the share price rises depending on the company right?

That's a good attitude to have! And yes, if you are willing to wait long enough, then yes theoretically you should be able to always make money. Just beware that you may have to wait a VERY long time in some cases. The classic example being Cisco - if you bought in March 2000, it would have taken you nearly 20 years to break even, even with the dividends.

Also keep in mind that you may lose in terms of opportunity cost.

>Or do these shares expire

No, shares don't expire. They are yours until you sell them or the company goes bankrupt or gets acquired.

>don’t work after losing the amount you put in

Not exactly sure what you mean.. If the company goes bankrupt, then yes you can lose all the money you put in and then of course, the company won't exist anymore so the shares are meaningless. As long as you are buying stocks, that's the only way to lose all the money you put in.

body:
If you bought Microsoft at the top of the dot com bubble it would take you 15 years to break even.  Bought Cisco? You are still in the red.

"Who cares about the price, just be in it for the long run because Cathie is a magic woman" is awful advice. People should absolutely be weary about this, and buying at too high of a price can and will RUIN your portfolio. No amount of "long run" can justify overpaying for things. Prices for SPCE and MAXR are already up 15% after hours. This is a bubble.

author: Fholse
body:
Cisco was the most valuable Company on the planet with a market cap of $569 billion in 2000. Enjoy this write-up from march 20 2000, of how it was destined to only go up:

https://www.bizjournals.com/sanjose/stories/2000/03/20/story2.html

author: DPX90
body:
The daily it's a bubble post. Don't take it wrong, I agree with you to some degree, but I feel like it's a one sided list, while it would be worth to consider the differences to the dotcom bubble too, since many companies are backed up fundamentally a lot more than that time.

Tesla is a pretty complex topic. While I don't agree that they can't potentially be the new paradigm and disrupt several different industries at once, valuation still matters. The best example is Cisco. During the dotcom bubble, the sentiment was that the internet is the future, and any company associated with it can be a huge winner. Cisco, as basically an infrastructure building/supply chain company of the next big thing was a sure bet also.

* Did the internet became the future? In a way, yes!
* Was Cisco a good company? It was and it's still solid today.
* Did these factors justify the huge valuation during that period? **Hell no!**

Every time I argue about Tesla being overvalued, fans say "bUt It'S dA fUtuReE!!!4!". Yes, it very well might be, but it still can be overvalued now as an investment...duh.

I was just wondering today how interesting it is that we see potential bubbles forming in both the stock market and "commodities" like crypto (you listed these as if they were one market, but IMO they are very different assets). We essentially have the dotcom bubble PLUS the Dutch tulip mania at the same time.

Paul Weinstein, an analyst with Credit Suisse First Boston, believes a $1 trillion market capitalization (stock price multiplied by shares outstanding) is within reach in a few years. He said Cisco's stock has increased 1,000 times, a perfect 100 percent annual return since it launched its IPO in 1990. A low P/E usually signals investors are uncomfortable," Mr. Kelly said.

As a reference, in 2000 Cisco's multiple of 120 compares to Microsoft Corp.'s multiple of 55 and Intel Corp.'s multiple of 42. Yet their values are below Cisco.

https://www.bizjournals.com/sanjose/stories/2000/03/20/story2.html

Go look at Cisco's stock and zoom all the way back to 2000.

Their stock crashed 10x within a year and today 20 years later is still only worth 40% of the peak.

author: rnjbond
body:
A real crash would mean the market drops and doesn't recover for an extended period of time, if ever. Like the Nikkei or the NASDAQ from its 2000 highs (took fifteen years to retrace it). Even a blue chip like Cisco is down 40% from its 2000 highs.

People here are too young to know how unprecedented the 90s bubble was. We may see pockets like that, I think TSLA and Bitcoin fit the bill. But the overall market may be expensive, but this is not comparable to the tech bubble.

author: sarcastic_analyst
body:
I think if you look at index funds overall -  US SandP fund, Bond fund, International Index fund, then they perform better than most mutual funds in same categories.....as Warren Buffet says .....the index funds outperform most broker advisors because of lower fees and the fact that brokers have to add on there %.....basically buying same stocks/funds at end of the day.

The question you need to ask is what is the alternative?  Buying individual stocks is way more risky unless you are heavy into the analysis world....even then no gaurantee.

Average investor should be in index funds for significant part of their savings.

I went the way of individual stocks on several occassions and got burnt.....Nortel was can't miss in the late 90's....it was the Cisco of the day....now worthless.  If I invested in index funds (basically the general market) I would have earned 8%- 10% per year.....

I switched strategies in 2005 and much better results.  

Doesn't mean you can't take 10-15% of portfolio and take some additional risk....just means your overall investing strategy has balance and logic

author: AXdssd5as
body:
But if Bitcoin is being bought by investors as a store of value, i.e. how it is marketed as "digital gold", isn't this a bit dangerous since unlike gold, it can have identical competitors, and just because it is on-top now doesn't mean it always will be?

Gold has been a store of value because of its relatively finite quantity at any given time, but also because of several other qualities that are hard to replicate in other materials (it doesn't rust or corrode or tarnish, it is soft enough to be shaped easily, it is rare but not too rare etc).

Unlike gold, Bitcoin is replicable, either identically or near-identically, which means that it could become more like a stock in the future, and if that's the case, the fact that it is on-top now doesn't necessarily mean this will continue? Companies that have seemed unassailable (AT&T, IBM, Kodak) have fallen, meanwhile gold has been around for however many thousands of years and still hasn't been dethroned (except maybe eventually by Bitcoin!)

I had 20k in savings so I built a portfolio based on growth and also high dividends about 7 months ago.
I have shares in TSM, MSFT, IBM, AVB, and LUMN.

My TSM position is up 125% and my MSFT is up 11%... the rest are up, but mostly float on average around 5%.

Looking back I am happy I diversified, but I obviously could have been up much more if I went all in on TSM.

For reference I'm up 4k on that 20k from diversifying rather than being up 25k if I put it all in TSM.

But the caveat to this is you have to land in the right stock. I had a 1/5 chance according to my portfolio for this strategy to work.

author: Somethingdifferent39
body:
I average up all the time. I started buying SQ at $98 and stopped around $160. I would still buy more at $218 but its already taken over a large portion of my portfolio so I wont for diversity reasons.

To your question, you will likely find that you will be mpre successful averaging up than down, as counter intuitive as it may seem. You could have averaged up on AMZN, AAPL, and MSFT at any point in the past decade and be very happy with the result.

Likewise you could have averaged down on XOM, IBM, and GE over the last 10 years and been very dissapointed. More often than not the long term trend is justified. Your job as an investor is to figure out where the company is headed next.

Her scenario is she doesn’t need this money within the next 10 years at least. She is still working self employed. She is 60 doesn’t have any debt has other passive income (rentals), cure t holding are random funds her employer had with mass mutual they will be liquidated into cash and put into a traditional Roth. Risk tolerance I would say a 5 out of 10 (10 being very risky).

My thoughts where to select a handful of dividend stocks for 50-60% i like names such as jnj, mmm, xom, T, pg, Abbv, csco, ibm (trying to stick with dividend champion companies that are reasonably priced now..) etc and then the remaining 20% would be in a couple vanguard bond funds and remaining 20% in a vanguard s&p fund.

Thanks,

author: redderper
body:
At the moment it is because low code isn't that popular yet outside of government, banking and insurance (which IBM and Pega is mostly focused on). Salesforce is very popular though, but mostly as a CRM platform. The others focus more on what is called BPM or process automation.

Seems that Mendix, Appian, Bettyblocks and Microsoft are more focused on commercial markets and offer simpler and cheaper solutions (I believe Bettyblocks is actually no-code). Which is smart because there are a lot of potential customers in that market that don't use low code platforms yet. So I do see future in it, but the question is which companies are going to become the market leaders.

author: tomorland
body:
Ok, let's talk about Tesla.

For the record, I do not own any Tesla stock, nor do I own a Tesla car, nor do I plan to own either in the foreseeable future. (I \*do\* own an electric car that I built myself. Love it. Planning to convert my daughter's car soon.)

Here's why I think Tesla's stock value *could* be justified and *may* continue to go up.

1. Tesla is a car company that makes a profit. It's not Amazon. But then, Amazon *didn't* make a profit for a long, long time. Amazon's retail product delivery service still doesn't make a profit. Who could have known that Amazon would beat Microsoft, Oracle, Cisco, Walmart, Akamai and all the others at cloud services? AWS is the meat of Amazon's profits. Who could have predicted this when they were just a book store?
2. Tesla is also a consumer goods company. Solar power is just the tip of the iceberg. Heat pumps, Smart Homes, Satellite Networking... Yes, it's a tech company -- but it's more than that, it's a *BRAND*. Brand is far more valuable than innovation. The story you sell is more effective than the product you sell, *especially* if it's an also-ran product...
3. Musk only knows one way to manage -- like a startup. Still going strong, like a start-up, after all these years.
4. Leverage. Space-X, Boring Co. Tesla and whatever else comes along -- Grid-scale electrical storage? Off-grid self-sufficient housing? Insurance services? They all share tech between them. Tesla's Octo-valve, for instance. Almost certainly was designed by an aerospace engineer at Space-X.
5. Tesla isn't Apple, or Amazon, or Microsoft. It's more like Java (the programming language) in the late 1990s.  Java didn't do anything better than any other language could do. It was a far worse language than many other more suitable, more mature ones. It failed at its main promise (write once, run anywhere!) Most seasoned programmers laughed at it. They said it wouldn't last. And yet...

So, forget about the cars. Tesla is a *brand*. It's a consumer technology-goods company that got it's start with cars, like Amazon got its start with books until it found gold in cloud services. Tesla is still digging, currently using a constellation of satellites... It won't end there. That's guaranteed.

Having said that, keep in mind that any one of IBM, Oracle, Walmart or a dozen others *could* have eaten Amazon's lunch at any time. Amazon was lucky no one tried very hard.

author: walnuts24
body:
Good points.  As a reference, prior to 2020 (2010-2019) my annualized return has been about 18%.  Usually my individual stocks way outperform my index funds or mutual funds but I don’t have time to research for hours and hours.  My investments have always been owned longer than a year, most closer to 5+ years or almost the entire duration.  My main holdings over the 2010-2019 (pre-COVID) period were Microsoft ($28 cost basis), Disney ($46 cost basis), Nike ($55) and Xylem ($50).  I got ‘lucky’ and dumped Disney when Iger stepped down in February out of nowhere at $135.  I never bought back in and I should have. I did have some duds such as IBM and GE over that time that dragged me down, but I can’t complain.  This year I did well but I traded more than usual and lost my cost basis for everything out of panic selling.  The trades I made were Zillow ($78-115), Starbucks ($78-103), Penn ($3-15), NIO ($3-16) and some losses like Slack and CARA.  Now I have only my 401K and a bit of sector ETF (I love ARKK).  

Hindsight, I screwed up and should have just held all my positions but I just kept jumping around to catch waves.  I didn’t realize they were never going to stop! Haha. Now I’m looking at everything thinking “they have to correct” and I’m not sure they will.  Which is why I have yet to get back in.
